messageBody:
>Ilja wrote:
>What's a test category?

I believe some of the features stem from NUnit 2.2. Categories is an
excellent idea that I use quite a bit. In essence, you are group
tests (fixtures etc) into groups and just run those groups.

For example, about 1/10 of my tests are database related and quite
slow. So I have a category that excludes those tests during
development. (Of course, prior to checking in, I run the entire
suite).

Another example, I am working on several classes that are coupled
together logically but perhaps not structurally (aka within the xUnit
list). So, during development, I create a category with the explicit
classes that I working on to minimize the execution of my tests.

I also like the idea of having explicit tests - tests that only run if
explicitly requested. I use NUnit as a tool for running diagnostics
on our applications. These *tests* are not really tests, but rather I
am using NUnits ability to pick them up so that I can a GUI interface
without having to program one.




On Thu, 8 Jul 2004 10:55:14 +0200, Ilja Preuss <preuss@...> wrote:
> Paul Holser wrote:
>
> > my wish list for "TigerUnit":
> >
> > -- use native Java assertion mechanism in Assert methods
>
> What is the business value?
>
> > -- make Assert no longer a superclass of TestCase. to use Assert's
> > methods unqualified, use static import
>
> Again, what's the value?
>
> > -- annotations for test fixture, test method, setup method, teardown
> > method, fixture setup method, fixture teardown method, test category
> > a la NUnit
>
> Annotations for test methods sounds like a reasonable idea. Why would
> you want this for setup etc. ? What's a test category?
>
> > -- ability to build suites by mixing and matching on category,
> > package, and other criteria...
>
> You can already do this, as far as I can tell, by using either publicly
> available extensions to junit or custom suite/testrunner
> implementations.
>
> Cheers, Ilja
